awd_titl_txt: Workshop on Undergraduate Teaching with Mathematics and Statistics Action Technologies
awd_abstract_narration:
This workshop aims to contribute to the national need for high quality mathematics teaching by improving the preparation of future mathematics teachers.  The workshop focuses on helping mathematics education faculty develop expertise with mathematics action technologies. These technologies include tools and devices that compute and display the results of mathematical equations, such as graphing calculators and computer simulations.  This interactive workshop will provide mathematics education faculty with opportunities to learn how to use mathematics action technology as learners.  In addition, the faculty participants will consider the ways they might implement these technologies in their courses for prospective secondary mathematics teachers. Approximately 50 faculty from across the U.S. will participate in the workshop, gaining practice with mathematics action tools that span the needs of different mathematics and statistics courses. 

The main goal of this project is to improve faculty expertise in teaching undergraduate courses for future secondary mathematics teachers.  To this end, it will plan and implement a 2.5-day workshop for instructors of undergraduate mathematics content and pedagogical methods courses that are intended to prepare future teachers to teach mathematics with technology. The project will provide beginning through advanced level sessions in which faculty will learn how to use mathematics action technologies as learners and consider the ways they might implement them in their courses. Specifically the project will: 1) Provide workshop sessions on a variety of mathematics action tools that span the needs of those working in geometric, algebraic/function, and statistics contexts; 2) Provide workshop sessions that range (and build) from basic functionality to more advanced functionality for each mathematics action tool; 3) Provide workshop sessions that allow participants to work at their own pace on specific functions of a mathematics action tool of their choice with the support of experts; 4) Provide workshop leaders for each technology tool who use the tool in content courses and methods courses;  and 5) Evaluate the effectiveness of the workshop through perceived impact on faculty expertise and self-reports of mathematics action tool use in instruction. Workshop participants are expected to leave with the expertise needed to begin to incorporate mathematics action technologies into their courses. What is learned about the development of participants' self-efficacy in use of mathematics action technology will inform future workshop design and has the potential to also inform future educational research studies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Multiple professional organizations have pointed to the importance of preparing secondary mathematics teachers [PSMTs] to teach using mathematical action technologies. However, a recent nationwide survey of accredited PSMT preparation programs found that many include few (if any) opportunities to engage with a variety of mathematical action technologies, often due to a lack of faculty expertise (McCulloch et al., 2021). To address this issue, a 6-day workshop on teaching undergraduate courses for PSMTs with mathematical action technologies was conducted. The workshop provided opportunities for faculty who teach mathematics, statistics, and methods courses to learn about technologies that are appropriate for use in their courses and are commonly used in secondary schools. 

A total of 235 faculty and graduate students applied to take part in the Workshop. In selecting participants we worked to have the pool be representative of all accredited secondary mathematics education programs in the US according to geographical location and size of institution (as classified by Carnegie), with a priority given to faculty from minority serving institutions. Ultimately we invited 70 Workshop participants (including 10 graduate students) from 50 universities across 27 states and two countries. Research related to the Workshop included faculty self-efficacy for using the technologies and teaching with the technologies, as well as examination of their implementation of the technologies in instruction. 

Intellectual Merit 

On average the 70 Workshop participants reported an increase in their self-efficacy for using and for teaching with the three focus technologies on all items for each technology. On the pre- survey the mean reported self-efficacy for using the focus technologies ranged from 1.37 to 2.75 (not at all comfortable/a little comfortable) and post Workshop reported self-efficacy for using the focus technologies ranged from 3.02 to 4.18 (somewhat comfortable/comfortable). The item that participants reported the least confidence with using on the post- survey (i.e., using GeoGebra CAS tools) was still higher than the highest item reported on the pre-survey (i.e., graphing functions using sliders in Desmos). Similarly, the Workshop participants reported improved self-efficacy for teaching using the three focus technologies on all items. On the pre- survey the mean reported self-efficacy for teaching with the focus technologies ranged from 1.28 to 3.04 (not at all comfortable/somewhat comfortable) and post Workshop reported self-efficacy for using the focus technologies ranged from 2.81 to 4.05 (a little comfortable/comfortable). At the end of the Workshop the participants reported being least confident with teaching using CODAP sampling tools and most confident teaching using Desmos to create graphs of functions using sliders. Results from the 58% of participants who completed the follow up questionnaire provide further evidence that many Workshop participants are in fact using (or planning to use) the focus technologies in their instruction. While this finding is promising, it is important to note the limitation of non-response on the follow up questionnaire as it is possible that those that did not respond do not intend to use any of the technologies. 

There are so few opportunities for higher education faculty to come together and take significant time to learn about teaching with technologies in ways that are connected to their specific course content and context, the findings from this study suggest that workshops designed in ways aligned with the research base on high quality professional development is a worthwhile effort and there should be more of them. 

Broader Impact 

Through this Workshop we aimed to support the community of math teacher educators [MTEs] through the development of knowledge and skills related to mathematical action technologies that are free, cutting-edge, web-based, and open-source - the go-to software for secondary mathematics teachers due to their accessibility on any platform. This workshop increased the knowledge and self-efficacy of at least 70 MTEs, who typically teach 30 PSMTs per year, thus we anticipate reaching approximately 2,100 PSMTs per year. If those PSMTs have future classrooms with an average of 25 students and teach 5 classes per day (a conservative estimate), then we will have reached approximately 262,000 high students in the first year the PSMTs enter the classroom. This broad reach has great potential to influence the STEM pipeline and does not account for the MTEs sharing their knowledge with colleagues.
